author: mightypenguin
content:
Where/What's the latest work on setting the gas limit per block post-merge?
I was hoping to advocate for a monotonically increasing gas limit over time if node operators won't be voting on it anymore but I haven't read current proposals yet.

author: treyzania
content: indefinitely increasing gas limit is unwise

author: treyzania
content: it very likely will increase just because the game theory is different now but it would be a very bad idea to increase it massively

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> Gas limit mechanism will remain untouched at the merge. Meaning pos block proposers rather than pow miners have the lever in their block construction

author: mightypenguin
content:
Hardware/Network capacity should increase over time. And I think we all agree that the gas limit should increase over time in some fashion.
Currently it's increased in big increments at network upgrades.
But we could schedule in a conservative increase over time that more predictable.
For the sake of discussion, say 5-15% increase per year.
That also makes it easier for node operators to schedule hardware replacement as well.

author: treyzania
content: increases over time aren't predictable and Moore's law is essentially at its end

author: treyzania
content: real increases in performance right now are mainly from improving client implementation, which also isn't something we can rely on mathematically

author: mightypenguin
content: Are you saying that it's not realistic to expect clients to be able to handle 5% gas inflation a year?

author: treyzania
content: a sustainable network long term should not rely on the expectation that users buy new hardware on a regular basis

author: treyzania
content: with a floating gas limit this can be adjusted on an as-needed basis

author: mightypenguin
content: Sorry that's why I was curious if there was a discussion on-going somewhere else already.
